name: Idli
Ingredients: 2–3 tsp moong dal (optional, for extra thickness)
Instructions: Wash tur dal thoroughly 2–3 times and add water. Optionally add moong dal for extra thickness.
Close the pressure cooker lid and cook on medium-high heat until steam releases, then reduce heat and cook for 10 more minutes.
Mash the cooked dal well.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they pop, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add hing, curry leaves, dry red chilies, fenugreek seeds, and chopped onion. Cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add chopped tomato, bottle gourd (or pumpkin), carrot, and drumsticks. Mix well.
Ensure all vegetables are chopped evenly. Add water, cover, and cook on medium heat for 10–15 minutes or until soft.
Add the mashed dal, sambar masala, coriander powder, turmeric powder, tamarind pulp, jaggery, salt, red chili powder, and more water if needed.
Mix well and simmer on medium heat for 10 minutes.
Sambar is ready to serve.

name: Sabudana Khichdi
instructions: Take the sago and separate the pearls, ensuring they are not sticking together.
Combine roasted peanuts (coarsely pounded), sugar, and salt with the sago.
Heat ghee and oil together in a pan. Add cumin seeds, then green chilies and curry leaves. Let them splutter for a few seconds.
Add the sago-peanut mixture to the pan and mix well with the seasoning on low heat.
Toss the mixture continuously for 8–10 minutes or until the sabudana turns translucent.

name: Bread Pakora
Instructions: In a bowl, mix besan, rice flour, turmeric, red chili powder, ajwain, salt, and baking soda.
Add water gradually to make a slightly thick batter (similar to batata bhaji batter).
Beat the batter well for 3–4 minutes to make it airy and light.
Add chopped coriander leaves, mix, and let the batter rest for 15–20 minutes.
Cut bread slices into triangles. You can keep or remove the edges as preferred.
Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Dip each bread piece into the batter, ensuring it's coated evenly.
Deep fry the coated bread slices until golden and crispy on both sides.
Drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve hot with tamarind chutney, green chutney, or tomato sauce.

name: Dosa
instructions: Wash and soak rice in water for 4–5 hours.
Separately, wash and soak urad dal, chana dal, and fenugreek seeds together for the same duration.
Grind the soaked dal mixture into a fine, smooth paste using minimal water and transfer it to a large bowl.
Rinse poha (no need to soak) and grind it with soaked rice to form a smooth paste.
Combine both pastes in a bowl, add salt (and optional 1/2 tsp sugar), and mix well. Adjust consistency if needed.
Cover the batter and let it ferment overnight (10–12 hours) in a warm place.
After fermentation, stir the batter well. Add a little water if the batter is too thick.
Heat a dosa tawa or non-stick pan and lightly grease it with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it evenly in a circular motion to form a thin dosa.
Roast on medium heat until the bottom is golden brown and crisp.
Fold and serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or your preferred side.

name: Misal Pav
Instructions: Roast coconut in a pan until reddish, then blend with fried onion, garlic, ginger, and tomato.
In the same pan, fry the blended masala with coriander powder, goda masala, and red chili powder.
Cook mataki with turmeric and salt, then mix with the masala.
Add water, salt, and jaggery, and cook for 7-8 minutes.
For serving, layer mataki, boiled potatoes, pohe, farsan, and misal kat in a bowl.
Garnish with onion, coriander, and fine shev.
Serve with ladi pav and a lemon slice.

name: Upma
Instructions: Heat a pan and roast rava in ghee (or oil) on low heat for 7–8 minutes without letting it turn pink. Avoid using a non-stick pan to prevent scratches. Set aside.
In another pan, heat oil, fry peanuts until reddish, and remove.
Add mustard seeds, cumin, asafoetida, chopped onion, green chillies, and curry leaves.
Sauté for 5–6 minutes until onions soften.
Add the roasted rava, mix well, then add hot water, salt, and sugar.
Stir, cover, and cook for 3–4 minutes.
Mix well, garnish with coriander. Serve hot with peanuts, grated coconut, and more coriander on top.

name: Poha
Instructions: Wash poha 3–4 times, drain, and let it rest.
Heat oil, fry peanuts until reddish, and set aside.
In the same oil, add mustard seeds, let them pop, then add cumin, hing, curry leaves, chopped onion, and green chilies.
Sauté until onions turn light golden, then add turmeric.
Add poha, salt, and sugar; mix well.
Cover and steam on low heat for 7–8 minutes.
Add coriander, mix, and serve garnished with more coriander, fine sev, fried peanuts, and a lemon slice.

name: Aloo Paratha

stuffing: 1 small or 1/2 big finely chopped Onion

Instructions: Mix wheat flour and salt, then gradually add water to make a medium-consistency dough.
Add a little oil, knead again, coat with oil, cover, and rest for 30–45 minutes.
For stuffing, mash boiled potatoes and mix with chopped onion, green chilies, coriander powder, red chili powder, amchur (or lemon juice), salt, and chopped coriander. Let it rest for 10–15 minutes.
To make paratha, knead dough again, roll into a 6-inch disc, place a ball of stuffing in the center, fold edges like a modak, remove excess dough, and roll gently.
Cook on a heated pan, flipping and applying butter, ghee, or oil until golden on both sides.
Serve hot with pickle and curd.

name: Appam
Instructions: Mix rice, chana dal, masoor dal, moong dal, urad dal, poha, and fenugreek seeds, wash well, and grind into coarse flour.
Soak the mixture for 5–6 hours, then drain and blend into a coarse paste with minimal water.
Ferment the batter for 12–14 hours or overnight, stirring by hand to speed up fermentation.
Add green chilies, cumin seeds, ginger, salt, and optional veggies like capsicum or carrots.
Heat oil in an appe pan, fill the molds with batter, cover, and cook for 2–3 minutes on medium heat.
Flip and cook the other side until golden.
Serve with chutney or sambar.

name: Paneer Butter Masala
Instructions: Cut tomatoes, onions, beetroot, and cashews, and place them in a pot.
Put the pot in a cooker with water and cook on medium heat for 1 whistle.
Blend the ingredients into a smooth paste without adding water.
Heat butter in a pan, add ginger garlic paste, and sauté for a minute.
Add the blended masala, cover, and cook for 7–8 minutes.
Stir in kitchen king masala, red chili powder, and cook until oil separates.
Add salt, water, crushed kasuri methi, and paneer.
Cover and cook for 4–5 minutes, then add fresh cream (or beaten cream) and mix well.
Serve with naan or paratha.

name: Dal Tadka
Instructions: Wash dal 2–3 times, then cook it in a pressure cooker with water, turmeric, and hing for 4 whistles.
Beat the dal and set aside.
Heat butter (or ghee/oil) in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin, then sauté onions until golden.
Add tomatoes, green chilies, spices, and garlic paste, and cook until tomatoes soften.
Add the cooked dal, adjust consistency with water, and cook for 5–7 minutes.
For the tadka, heat ghee, fry minced garlic and red chilies until golden, then pour over the dal.
Mix well and serve with jeera rice.

name: Chole Bhature
Instructions: Wash and soak chole overnight, then cook in a pressure cooker with enough water for 7–8 whistles.
For bhature, mix maida, rava, salt, baking soda, oil, and curd, then knead into a thick dough. Rest for 3 hours.
Heat oil in a pan, fry cumin seeds, bay leaves, and onions, then add tomatoes, ginger-garlic paste, and spices.
Cook until tomatoes soften, then add boiled chole, salt, and cook for 7–8 minutes.
For bhature, knead dough again, form balls, and roll into larger discs.
Fry in hot oil until puffed and golden.
Serve with chole masala.

name: Baingan Bharta
Ingredients: 1 tsp Garlic-Green chili paste (8-10 garlic cloves & 4-5 green chilies)
Instructions: Wash and slit the brinjal, then rub with oil and roast it on a foil-covered burner, rotating every 2 minutes until tender.
Peel the skin once cooled and mash the brinjal.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard and cumin seeds, curry leaves, and onions, frying until golden.
Add garlic-green chili paste, spices, and fry for 2-3 minutes.
Stir in mashed brinjal, roasted peanut powder, and salt, cooking for 4-5 minutes.
Finish with coriander leaves.
Serve with jawar, bajra, or rice bhakari.

name: Bhindi Masala
Instructions: Heat oil, add mustard seeds, cumin, hing, garlic, and curry leaves. Avoid frying garlic.
Wash, dry, and slice bhendi, then add to the pan and cook covered for 5 minutes.
Remove the lid and fry for 7-8 minutes to remove stickiness. For crunch, continue frying until golden.
Add spices, roasted peanut powder (or roasted chana dal, or coconut), and mix well.
Fry for another 3-4 minutes, then garnish with coriander leaves.
Lasuni masala bhendi is ready.

name: Rajma Chawal
Instructions: Soak kidney beans for 4-5 hours, then pressure cook with water and salt for 7-8 minutes on high flame, followed by 2 more whistles on medium-low.
Make brown onion paste by frying onions until golden, then grinding them with a splash of water.
Heat oil in a handi, add whole spices, ginger-garlic-chili paste, turmeric, tomato puree, salt, and powdered spices, and cook until oil separates.
Add the brown onion paste and cook for 10-12 minutes.
Add the boiled kidney beans, bring to a boil, then cook on low flame for 20-25 minutes.
Mash the rajma for a creamy texture, adjust salt, and add kasuri methi, garam masala, and fresh coriander.
Your rajma is ready!

method: Add all the chutney ingredients into a mixer grinder jar and grind it into a fine chutney.
Your special chutney for rajma chawal is ready.

name: Drumsticks Sabji

For Curry: Kanda Lasun Masala (Onion Garlic Masala): 2 tsp

Instructions: To make Drumstick Curry, first boil the drumsticks with salt, turmeric, and water for 1-2 whistles.
For the ground paste (Vatan), sauté onions in oil, then add grated dry coconut, ginger, and garlic, and grind them into a paste.
For the curry, heat oil in a pan, add mustard and cumin seeds, then add the ground paste, red chili powder, onion-garlic masala, coriander powder, and cook for a few minutes.
Add the boiled drumsticks with the water, mix well, and simmer until the curry thickens.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve.

Main Ingredients: 1 medium whole Cauliflower - cut into florets
For Masala Mixture: ½ tsp Degi Red Chilli Powder
In a bowl, add water, turmeric powder, degi red chilli powder, asafoetida, cumin powder, and mix everything properly.
For Aloo Gobi Sabzi: In a kadai, heat ghee and add cumin seeds, ginger, green chillies, and garlic. Saute for a few seconds.
Add the prepared masala mixture and saute until the ghee starts separating.
Now add cauliflower, potatoes, salt, water, and mix everything properly.
Cover and cook on low heat for 10-12 minutes.
Remove the lid and stir in the chopped coriander leaves. Switch off the flames and cover again, keeping it aside for 2-3 minutes.
Serve in a serving bowl and garnish with fresh coriander leaves.

Pakoda: Mix besan and salt well together and add water to make a thick paste.
Beat the paste really well for about 3-4 minutes and rest it for about 10 minutes.
Add ajwain, onion, coriander leaves and mix well.
Heat oil in a pan and drop small pakodas in it.
Fry pakodas well from all sides and take them out in a dish. Pakodas are ready.
Kadhi: Mix curd, besan, water, turmeric powder, and salt well together. No lumps of besan should be formed.
You can add sugar if you want.
Heat ghee in a pan and add cumin seeds. When cumin seeds splutter, add cloves, cinnamon, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves, and ginger. Fry well for about a minute.
Add chopped green chili and fry well.
Turn off the gas and add the curd mixture, water, and salt. Mix well.
Simmer the kadhi on low heat for about 10 minutes.
Drop the hot pakodas into the hot kadhi.
Tadka: Heat ghee in a pan and add red chili powder and dry red chilies.
Fry well and add this tadka into the kadhi.
Mix well, and kadhi pakoda is ready.

name: Stuffed Capsicum
Instructions: Roast peanuts in a pan until they change color.
Add grated dry coconut, roasted chana dal (or roasted besan), cumin seeds, chopped ginger, and garlic.
Roast everything together for 4–5 minutes.
Turn off the heat and mix in curry leaves. Let the mixture cool.

Blend half the roasted mixture with coriander leaves, Sunday masala, red chili powder, salt, sugar (optional), and the remaining half of the roasted mix to make a coarse powder. Do not use water while grinding.
Add a little water to this masala to make it slightly sticky for stuffing.
Wash and deseed the small capsicums. Rub a pinch of salt inside.
Stuff the capsicums with the prepared masala.
Heat oil in a pan, add the stuffed capsicums, cover and steam-cook for 3–4 minutes. Flip and cook evenly on all sides.
Push the capsicums to the side, add the remaining masala to the pan and roast well.
Mix everything and cook together for a couple of minutes.
Serve hot with chapati or rice.
Optional: For a rassa (gravy) version, add water to the remaining masala after frying.

name: Besan
Ingredients: Garlic-Green chili paste (8-10 Garlic cloves & 4-5 Green chilies)
Instructions: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, hing, and curry leaves.
Add chopped onion and sauté until light golden.
In a bowl, mix besan with water to make a lump-free paste.
Add garlic-green chili paste and turmeric powder to the pan and fry for a minute.
Pour in the besan mixture and add salt.
Stir continuously until the mixture thickens.
Cover and cook for 7–8 minutes on low heat.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with bhakari or rice.

name: Palak Paneer
Instructions: Heat oil in a pan, add tomato and green chili, cook covered for 3-4 minutes.
Add washed, chopped palak and a little water, cook uncovered for 3-4 minutes.
Cool the mixture and blend into a smooth puree.
Mix all dry spices with 2-3 tsp water to make a masala paste.
In a separate pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds, then garlic paste. Cook for a minute.
Add the prepared masala paste and cook until the oil releases.
Add the palak puree and salt. Cook for 5-6 minutes.
Add butter, kasuri methi, and cream. Mix well.
Add paneer cubes and cook for 4-5 minutes.
Serve hot with naan, kulcha, or paratha.

name: Tawa Pulao
Instructions: Heat up butter in a pan.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add finely chopped onion and fry it well for about 3-4 minutes.
Add ginger-garlic paste and mix well.
Add capsicum, carrot, french beans and fry for about 4-5 minutes.
Add tomato and green peas and cook everything well for 3-4 minutes.
Mash the veggies a little.
Add half of pav bhaji masala, red chili powder, salt and mix well.
Add rice, remaining masala, red chili powder, and mix thoroughly.
Be careful with the salt if you already added it while cooking rice.
Fry the rice on medium heat for about 4-5 minutes, stirring continuously.
Add finely chopped coriander leaves and mix well.
Tawa pulao is ready to serve.
You can enjoy it as-is or with raita.

kofta: Peel and grate the lauki (bottle gourd).
Squeeze the grated lauki and collect the juice in a bowl for later use.
Mix all ingredients for kofta (except oil) with the grated lauki.
Form small round balls or patties.
Heat oil in a frying pan and shallow fry the koftas until golden brown.
Drain on a kitchen towel to remove excess oil.
gravy: In a kadai, heat ghee and add cumin seeds to splutter.
Add garlic, ginger, green chillies and sauté well.
Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
Add asafetida, coriander powder, turmeric, and red chilli powder. Mix well.
Add chopped tomato and cook until soft and oil starts separating.
In a bowl, mix curd with red chilli powder and coriander powder, then add to the kadai.
Add reserved lauki juice, sugar, and about 1 cup of water. Mix well.
Simmer the gravy on low heat for 10–12 minutes.
Add the prepared koftas, turn off the flame, and cover for a few minutes to let the flavors absorb.
Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot with rotis, naan, or jeera rice.

gravy.title: Tomato Onion Gravy
Instructions: Heat oil in a wok, add the whole spices (cumin, bay leaves, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, pepper corns) and sauté for a minute.
Add onions, green chillies, ginger, and garlic cloves, cook until onions are light brown.
Add cashew nuts, melon seeds, tomatoes, whole Kashmiri red chili, and salt to taste. Cook for 4–5 minutes.
Add water, cover, and cook for 8–10 minutes.
Cool down the mixture and grind into a fine paste.

main.title: Paneer Lababdar
Instructions: Heat oil and butter in a wok, add ginger, and sauté for a minute.
Add the freshly prepared tomato onion gravy and cook for 7–8 minutes.
Add water to adjust the consistency, then add grated paneer and paneer cubes.
Mix gently without breaking the paneer cubes, cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add garam masala, kasuri methi, fresh cream, salt, and fresh coriander, mix well.
Serve hot with roti or paratha.

name: Pav Bhaji
Instructions: Cook potatoes and vegetables (cauliflower, capsicum, green peas, beetroot) in a cooker for 3 whistles.
Mash the cooked veggies and mix with the grated potatoes.
In a pan, heat some butter, fry onion, tomato, and spices until soft.
Add the mashed veggie mixture to the pan and simmer for 8–10 minutes.
Add butter for extra flavor.
Roast pav with butter and pav bhaji masala in a separate pan.
Serve the pav bhaji hot with roasted pav, chopped onion, coriander, and a slice of lemon.

name: Dal Khichdi
Instructions: Cook dal and rice with hing, turmeric, and salt in a pressure cooker for 3–4 whistles.
In a pan, heat oil and add mustard seeds. Once they pop, add onion, tomato, ginger garlic paste, and spices.
Fry the mixture until the tomato softens and the spices are well-cooked.
Mash the cooked dal and rice mixture and add water for the desired consistency.
Add the prepared tadka (spiced mixture) to the cooked khichadi and stir well.
Optional: For extra flavor, prepare a ghee tadka by frying cumin seeds, curry leaves, and dried red chilies in ghee and add to the khichadi.
Serve the dal khichadi hot with a dollop of ghee, mango pickle, and papad.

name: Misal Pav
Instructions: Roast grated coconut in a pan until it turns reddish.
Fry onion, garlic, ginger, and tomato, then blend with the roasted coconut to form a masala paste.
In the same pan, fry the blended masala with coriander powder, goda masala, and red chili powder.
Cook mataki separately with turmeric and salt until soft.
Mix cooked mataki with the fried masala paste.
Add water, salt, and jaggery; cook for 7–8 minutes to make the misal kat (spicy curry).
For serving, layer mataki, boiled potatoes, pohe, farsan, and misal kat in a bowl.
Garnish with chopped onion, coriander, and fine shev.
Serve hot with ladi pav and a slice of lemon.

For Making Kofte: 1 tsp Ginger garlic green chili paste
For Making Veg Maratha: 4 tbsp Oil
1/2 tsp Cumin seeds
7–8 Curry leaves
2 dried Red chilies
1 tbsp Kitchen king masala
1/2 tbsp Coriander powder
2 tsp Red chili powder
1 tbsp Khawa / Mawa
Salt to taste
Water

For Making Gravy: Heat up oil in a pan.
Mix well and fry until onion turns light golden.
Add tomato, dried coconut, sesame seeds and cashew nuts.
Mix well and fry for about 4–5 minutes until tomato cooks soft and mashes with onion.
Turn off the gas and let the masala cool down a little.
Transfer it into a blender jar and blend into a fine paste.
Try to use minimum or no water while blending.
For Making Kofte: Add carrot, coriander leaves, red chili powder, kitchen king masala, coriander powder, garlic-ginger-green chili paste and mix well.
Add corn flour, maida, salt and mix well again.
Add very little water (about a tablespoon) to make a thick dough.
The dough should not be thin at all.
Make small balls and flatten them slightly in the center.
Heat up oil in a pan.
Drop kofte in oil and fry until dark brown on both sides.
Take kofte out into a dish.
For Making Veg Maratha: Heat up oil in a pan.
Add cumin seeds, curry leaves, dried red chillies and the blended masala.
Mix well and fry on medium heat for about 4–5 minutes.
Add kitchen king masala, coriander powder, red chili powder, khoya and salt.
Mix well and fry until the oil releases.
Add water enough to make gravy.
Mix well and cook the gravy on medium heat for about 4–5 minutes.
Turn off the gas — veg Maratha is ready.
For serving: place kofte in a bowl and pour hot gravy over them.
You can also pour the gravy first and then add kofte.
Serve hot with naan, paratha, roti or jeera rice.

name: Mix Veg
Instructions: Heat butter in a pan, add onion, tomato, cashews, ginger, garlic, and sauté for 7–8 minutes.
Let it cool and blend into a smooth paste without water.
In another pan, shallow fry potatoes, then add cauliflower, carrot, beans, and cook covered until semi-soft.
Add capsicum and green peas, sauté briefly, then set the veggies aside.
In the same pan, heat butter, add red chili powder, coriander powder, kitchen king masala, and cumin powder. Sauté for a few seconds.
Add the blended masala paste and cook until oil separates.
Add salt, a pinch of sugar, some water, paneer cubes, and the cooked vegetables.
Mix everything well and simmer for 3–4 minutes.
Mixed veg paneer curry is ready to serve. Enjoy with naan or paratha.
